fig.title: : High resolution maps of dynactin's shoulder and pointed end A.
fig.label: Figure 1
fig.sd-panel: Schematic showing a dynein-dynactin-adaptor complex on microtubules
Schematic showing the domain architecture of dynactin.
Density improvements during processing. For each step, density shown is taken from the same p50 arm helix in the shoulder.
Map of the shoulder region. Density of the shoulder is colored in blue.
Map of the pointed end including Arp 11 (yellow); p62 (orange); p25 (brown) and p27 (light brown).

fig.title: : Structure of dynactin's shoulder A.
fig.label: Figure 2
fig.sd-panel: Gaussian surface rendering of dynactin showing the arrangement of the upper subdomain (greens) and the lower subdomain (blues) of the shoulder on the filament (gray). Different features are shown in different color shades, and the dimerization domain is colored magenta.
Upper subdomain of the shoulder, shown in ribbon (main) or surface representation (inset), with the arm, hook and paddle colored in shades of greens.
Lower subdomain of the shoulder, shown in ribbon (main) or surface representation (inset), with the arm, hook and paddle colored in shades of blue.

fig.title: : Arrangement of dynactin's shoulder subunits A.
fig.label: Figure 3
fig.sd-panel: The structure of the lower subdomain from the shoulder showing the organization of p150 (purple), p24 (yellow) and the two copies of p50 (p50-A in red, p50-B in pink). The N and C termini of each chain are shown. A Gaussian surface rendering of the lower subdomain is colored by feature (blues and magenta, inset).
The dimerization domain of the shoulder. Subunits from the lower subdomain are colored, with p50-A in red, p50-B in pink and p150 in purple. * marks equivalent features in D.

Helical bundle break in the lower subdomain arm, showing how the three helices in the arm break and reform after a twist. p24 (yellow) forms a short loop at the break, whereas p50 forms a longer loop, which is ordered in p50-A (red), and disordered in p50-B (pink), modelled by a dotted line. # marks equivalent features in D.
D. Secondary structure diagrams for the segments of p150, p50 and p24 within dynactin's shoulder. Helices H1-8 and S1 are labelled for p50-A and p50-B.

fig.title: : Alternative conformations of p50-A and p50-B A.
fig.label: Figure 4
fig.sd-panel: Secondary structure diagram of p50-A and p50-B colored in rainbow from N- to C- termini in the shoulder. Helices H1-8 and S1 are labelled for p50-A and p50-B.
Ribbon diagram of the lower subdomain of the shoulder showing the path of p50-A (B) and p50-B (C), colored as in A.
The N-terminal halves of p50-A (D) and p50-B (E) adopt different conformations in each subdomain (lower subdomain shown), colored as in A.

fig.title: : The organization of the pointed end A.
fig.label: Figure 5
fig.sd-panel: The structure of the pointed end showing p62 (orange), p25 (brown) and p27 (light brown) in cartoon representation. Arp11 (yellow) and the filament are shown as a Gaussian surface rendering of the model. Metal ions in p62 are colored gray, with the metal ion coordinating the N and C termini of p62 highlighted (arrow).

Detailed structure of p62 (cartoon), colored from N to C termini in blue, cyan, green, yellow, orange then red. Dotted boxes show the different structural features of p62. Metal ions in p62 are colored gray and are numbered.
Secondary structure diagram of p62, colored as in B.

fig.title: : Pointed end cargo adaptor interaction sites A.
fig.label: Figure 6
fig.sd-panel: Site 1 in the disordered loop of p62 (orange, in clear density), binds to each cargo adaptor (BICDR1 in yellow, Hook3 in purple, BICD2 in green). Density can be seen between p62 and the adaptor at low threshold. BICDR1- and Hook3-containing maps are filtered to 6 Å.

Residues on dynactin's pointed end (cartoon) that interact with cargo adaptors are shown as spheres, colored according to which adaptor they bind (yellow denotes binding to BICDR1, purple to Hook3 and green to BICD2). Binding sites 2-4 are shown in boxes.

Conservation of the surface residues plotted onto the density from the pointed end map, filtered to 6 Å. Sites 2-4 for cargo adaptor interaction are marked on the front face and end face. Conservation scores are from ConSurf, with lower conservation shown in green, and higher conservation in purple.

Pulldowns of pointed end site 1-4 mutants using Strep-Hook3 (D) or Strep-BICD2 (E). Binding is shown relative to the binding of the wildtype pointed end construct (dashed lines). * shows p<0.05. For BICD2, p=0.06 for Site 1 mutant, and p=0.1 for Site 4 mutant. Data presented as mean ±SEM, n=3. Statistical significance calculated using ANOVA with Tukey's test for multiple comparisons.

fig.title: : Docked p150 interaction sites overlap with adaptor binding sites A.
fig.label: Figure 7
fig.sd-panel: Density representation of the p150-docked structure (solid blue in left inset, transparent in right) superposed over the high resolution pointed end map shows where the coiled coil sits.

Crosslinks (red dotted lines) connecting residues (shown in red spheres) between either CC1B (upper panel, in yellow) or CC1A (lower panel, in purple) and the pointed end (light orange and light brown).

Residues on the pointed end that interact with the p150 or cargo adaptors are shown as spheres. Residues are colored based on their interaction partners. Those that interact with the p150 projection are shown in blue, with interactions with cargo adaptors shown in yellow (BICDR1), purple (Hook3) and green (BICD2). Sites 2-4 are shown in boxes.
